Executive Summary
EPA RMP Submission Document

Croda, Inc. seeks to provide a safe work environment for their employees as well as ensure the safety of individuals offsite.  In addition, Croda is keenly aware of the potential environmental impacts of their operations and they are committed to minimizing the negative effects of their processes on the environment.

A. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Croda, Inc. has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respon to control and contain the release.

B. Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled.

Croda, Inc. is a worldwide supplier for the personal care, household, pharmaceutical and manufacturing industries.  There are four substances regulated by the EPA RMP Rule that are found above threshold quantities at the site, including:

D. General Accidental Release Prevention Program Steps

The following describes the prevention steps in place at the Croda Mill Hall, PA site:

Croda complies with OSHA PSM (29 CFR 1910.119) for all processes using ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, epichlorohydrin and methyl chloride.

Croda utilizes many systems to control their process.  Some systems include one or more of the following:  vents, relief valves, check valves, scrubbers, oxidizers, manual shut-off valves, automatic shut-off valves, interlocks, excess flow valves, rupture disks, alarms and procedures.

Croda utilizes systems to mitigate the consequences.  Some systems include one or more of the following: dikes, enclosures, sprinkler systems and deluge systems.  In addition, Croda is up to date and/or reviewing 9for continuous improvement) other elements of the Prevention Program, including:  

* Training
* Employee Participation
* Operating Procedures
* Mechanical Integrity
* Compliance Audits (most recent: September, 2000)
* Accident Investigations
* Management of Change
* Safe Work Practices
* Contractor Safety

E. Five-Year Accident History

In the past five years, there have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or s

ignificant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

F. Emergency Response Program

Croda in Mill Hall, PA maintains a written emergency response program that is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.  

The overall emergency response at the site is coordinated with the Clinton County Emergency Response.  This organization is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The site has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations.  

G. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Croda, Inc. is constantly seeking to improve the safety of the plant.  Recommendations from Process Hazard Analyses, Incident Investigations, Compliance Audits, etc. are continuously implemented into day-to-day operations.

Future safety improvements include:

* Construction of new fire water storage tank.
* Relocation of the flammable and toxic storage to a remote area of the facility.
* New storage and distribution system for methyl chloride.
* New distribution systems for propylene oxide and ethylene oxide.
* Construction of two new, state-of-the-art reactor systems for Alkoxylation reactions.
* Automation, including safety-related interlocks, of existing reactor systems.
